title: 106_hr515
content: The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children in the United States aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings. The United States leads in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death compared to other industrialized countries. A 1997 CDC study found that the rate of unintentional firearms-related deaths for children under 15 in the US was 9 times higher than in 25 other industrialized countries combined. Additionally, a study in 1987 revealed that most unintentional gunshot wounds among children in California involve handguns. A study in the June 12, 1996, issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association found that unintentional gunshot wounds among children in California most often involve handguns. Another study in December 1995 discovered that children as young as 3 years old have the finger strength to fire most commercially available handguns. Firearms are currently the only products manufactured. The study revealed that young children have the finger strength to fire a high percentage of commonly available handguns. There is strong public support for safety regulations in the firearms industry, as firearms are not subject to minimum safety standards unlike other products in the United States. A study with the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy found that 74% of Americans support safety regulations for the firearms industry. It was noted that many trigger locks and safety devices currently available are inadequate in preventing accidental discharge or children from accessing firearms. Regulation of handgun discharge protection products. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children. Regulations will establish a minimum safety standard for these products, including those permanently installed in handguns. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children by establishing a standard ensuring quality and construction to prevent unauthorized handgun operation. Test protocols from the Code of Federal Regulations may be considered in developing this standard. The Secretary will issue a standard within 12 months of the Act's enactment, based on poison prevention packaging test protocols. The standard will take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of handgun discharge protection products that violate the Act. They can also require manufacturers and dealers to provide notice of associated risks and how to mitigate them. The Act prohibits the sale of products that violate regulations and requires notice of risks to the public and dealers. It also mandates bringing products into compliance, repairing or replacing them, and offering refunds if necessary. The Act mandates compliance with regulations by repairing, replacing, refunding, recalling, or submitting a plan for action. The Secretary can inspect areas where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured or stored. The Secretary can inspect places where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured, stored, or transported for commercial purposes to ensure compliance with the Act and its regulations. SEC. 5 of the Act makes it illegal for licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to sell handguns without a handgun discharge protection product that meets the standard. There is an exception for sales to government agencies. SEC. 6 requires warning labels on handguns. SEC. 6 of the Act mandates warning labels on handguns to prevent child access and potential injuries or death. The label must be displayed on packaging and materials in conspicuous and legible type. SEC. 6 of the Act requires warning labels on handguns to prevent child access. The label must be displayed on packaging or materials in a contrasting manner. Handguns transferred without packaging must have the warning label affixed. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's unintentional or self-inflicted gunshot wound from a handgun they sold after the Act's effective date. Enforcement measures are outlined in Section 8. The Secretary can impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for each violation of the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act. Additionally, the Secretary has the authority to revoke a federal firearms license for violations of the Act. Individuals affected by violations can pursue damages through a private cause of action in a US district court. Private Cause of Action allows individuals aggrieved by violations of the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act to bring a lawsuit in a US district court for damages, including attorney's fees. This remedy is in addition to other legal remedies available under common law or Federal/State law. Interested parties can also enforce the Act or seek injunctions against violations through private actions in court. Private Cause of Action allows individuals to bring a lawsuit in a US district court for damages or injunctions against violations of the Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act. This remedy is in addition to other legal remedies available under common law or Federal/State law. Interested parties can enforce the Act, and compliance with the Act does not relieve any person from liability under common law or State statutory law. (e) Effect on Private Remedies - Compliance with this Act or any order issued under it does not exempt anyone from liability under common law or State law. The failure of the Secretary to take action authorized by this Act is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties may be imposed on those who knowingly violate provisions of this Act regarding handgun discharge protection products. Criminal penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 2 years, may be imposed on individuals who knowingly violate provisions of this Act related to handgun discharge protection products. SEC. 9 of the Act states that it does not override state laws unless they are inconsistent with the Act and provide greater protection for children regarding handguns. SEC. 10 provides definitions. SEC. 10 of the Act defines key terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun."
